content.webTitle: The Fiver | Passive-aggressive accusations of unrealistic wage demands

fields.headline: Passive-aggressive accusations of unrealistic wage demands
fields.bodyText: MESSY ADDICKS The Fiver has never been competitive – chiefly because in the field of unfunny tea-timely publications about football we’ve never had any competition, apart from that time when The Fourer left us Behind The Times with its alpha-male take on The Footer, but that only made our attempts at humour feel mildly successful. Then there was Hatchet Man, the column that went in hardest. The good old days. So, imagine our surprise when, a little after 5pm on Monday, Charlton Athletic published what at first appeared to be the kind of biting satire we haven’t served up since (um, yeah, we’ll get back to you on that one) … with its behind-the-scenes take on contract negotiations, replete with passive-aggressive accusations of unrealistic wage demands and the influence of Mr 15%s. Only, it turns out it was a real-life actual football club statement. At some stage on Monday, Charlton owner and serial fan-angerer Roland Duchâtelet started emitting words in the fresh and funky style. “Lee [Bowyer, the manager] has been offered a one-year extension to his contract at a level which is approximately three times what he had since his last increase when he became permanent manager in September [2018]. It is six times what he earned when he started as assistant manager in 2017 and 50% more than what any Charlton manager previously had (excluding the Premier League years) … But Lee wanted much more.” Oof! As kicks to the swingers go to a manager who has just taken the club back into the Championship, it was quite a hefty one. The statement then rambled on about Bowyer’s choice of Mr 15% and hinted at a potential conflict of interest before revealing that the club would look for a new manager unless Bowyer chose to stay. You might think after a public doing-over that could only have been made worse had Bowyer been tarred and feathered while being force-fed £50 notes in The Valley centre-circle [or at one end of the ground due to safety concerns – Fiver Ed], he’d have launched himself through the door marked Do One. However … “Bowyer stays, the journey continues” cheered an Addicks social media disgrace post on Tuesday morning. “This has been a long process and I never wanted to leave, I love this club,” sniffed Bowyer. “I’d like to thank the owner for giving me the initial opportunity and now for continuing to believe in me,” he added, after scrawling his signature on a one-year extension. Duchâtelet has form when it comes to getting staff members to work for less than what they feel they are worth and it is not clear whether he has been successful in doing this with Bowyer. But in any case, Duchâtelet’s desperation to flog Charlton as soon as possible means Bowyer might have a new boss soon, one who won’t spit his dummy out at every bump in the road or seriously suggest that the Football League, in which the club competes, should buy the team. Miffed Addicks fans will certainly hope so. But this is football, where good owners are as rare as unfunny tea-timely emails about football. So, don’t hold your breath. FIVER LETTERS “If Paul Pogba wants an improvement in the hygiene standards of European dressing rooms (yesterday’s Fiver), he should start by refraining from airing his dirty laundry in public so often. As I’m sure those nice lads in the nappies would have been only to willing to advise him” – Justin Kavanagh. “I was surprised to read you would limit yourself to Tin-a Colada on the holiday c0cktail menu. Surely you’d also partake of a Manhat-Tin, Pink Tin, Tinapore Sling, Caipi-Tin-ha, Long Island Iced Tin, Tin Collins, Vodka Mar-Tin-i, Cosmopoli-Tin, Tin-let, Margari-Tin and a Mai Tin” – Alistair Drummond. “‘We want him for the long term,’ says Mel Morris (yesterday’s Bits and Bobs), who has had eight, or in Grandstand vidiprinter mode, (EIGHT) managers in his four years as Derby County owner” – Noble Francis. “Well, I finally summoned the courage to take on David Koppe’s dare and Googled ‘a$$fish’ (Fiver letters passim). Imagine my relief (tinged with disappointment?) to come face to face with these charming fellows” – James Brilliant. “A few years ago in the early days of Google’s search engine, I was working in an advertising agency and needed to find some corporate information about Richard Branson’s collection of companies. Without thinking, I Googled ‘Virgin Group’. Which didn’t turn out well” – Phil Welch. Send your letters to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can always tweet The Fiver via @guardian_sport. Newcastle boss Rafael Benítez has received a £12m-a-year offer to switch book-balancing on Tyneside for cash-splashing in the Chinese Super League as manager of Dalian Yifang. Perhaps because he can’t work out how Pep Guardiola has programmed him, Aidy Boothroyd is set to leave treble-winning Phil Foden out of his starting lineup for England’s European U-21 Championship opener against France. “It is knockout football from day one,” roared Boothroyd, smearing himself in war paint. Nigeria manager Thomas Dennerby’s mood was darker than an Alabama storm-season rain cloud after he claimed officials had left his team’s hopes of qualifying for the last 16 of the World Cup hanging by a thread. “If I gave you honest opinions, they would probably send me home,” he fumed, after Wendie Renard’s retaken penalty gave France a 1-0 win. “They don’t need support to win games.” And the Queen’s Celtic will play Sarajevo in the first leg of Big Cup first-round qualifying on 9 or 10 July because football never bloody stops!
